Award.AwardTitle: Integrative Analysis of Plasticity in Cell Fate Determination in Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Julia Bailey-Serres (University of California - Riverside)

CoPIs: Siobhan Brady and Neelima Sinha (University of California - Davis) and Roger Deal (Emory University)

From the germination of a seed to the fertilization events that lead to the next generation, plant development is exquisitely orchestrated by genetically determined processes that are fine-tuned by environmental cues. This entails the precise regulation of networks of genes in individual cells over the course of the plant life cycle. This project will decipher the complex regulation of genes within specific types of cells of the plant. This will be accomplished by transfer of methods pioneered by this team in the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana to three important crops: rice, alfalfa, and tomato. These technologies allow for the isolation of cell nuclei containing DNA and RNA and the ribosomes that translate mRNA into protein from targeted subpopulations of cells of a leaf, root or other organs, without the need for dissection. The new genetic resources developed will be used to study how development is perturbed by two major environmental threats to US agriculture: drought and flood. The outcome will be a greater understanding of the integration of plant development with environmental cues.

The project will have multiple broader impacts. Using parallel multi-tiered and computationally robust analyses, the project will address two important biological questions: How does gene regulation in the stem cells (meristem) of roots and shoots differ across species? How does environmental stress influence the development of specialized cell types in the root? The findings will provide insights that could facilitate downstream improvement of abiotic stress tolerance. It will also generate resources for the evaluation of cell-type specific expression in three important crops. The seed material and data sets will be shared with the plant genome research community through the NCBI Short Read Archive (SRA, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra) and Gramene (http://www.gramene.org/). Finally, the project will engage postdoctoral researchers and graduate students in advanced interdisciplinary training in biology and computational sciences, who will benefit from the experience of mentoring undergraduate students in research. Finally, the project will engage high school students in the classroom and the laboratory, develop teaching tools, and foster greater understanding of the importance of plant research to humankind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Integrative Plant Plasticity Project were: 1) to develop new methods for studying how plant gene activity is regulated at multiple levels and in specific cell types, 2) to apply these tools in agriculturally-relevant models (alfalfa, rice, tomato) as well as in a wild tomato species in order to define cellular and developmental responses to water stress (flooding and drought) that enable survival, and 3) to validate the technologies we developed in an agricultural setting.  

With respect to our first goal, we developed gene constructs, plant lines and methods for cell type-specific analysis of gene regulatory control at all relevant levels in each of our four target species. The development of these tools has not only allowed us to pursue our second and third goals, but also allowed many other important questions to be addressed by research groups around the world. This has been facilitated by sharing our biological reagents and highly detailed technical methods in detailed publications and workshops.

Regarding our second goal, we completed a highly comprehensive study of gene regulation in the roots of our four species in response to flooding conditions. These studies revealed that, despite vast evolutionary distances between the target species, plants have multiple conserved  pathways for regulating gene transcription in response to flooding. Plants also regulate the response at later steps in the gene regulatory pathway. Discoveries from our data provide a framework for understanding why some plants are tolerant and others are susceptible of flooding, which we anticipate will aid improvement of flooding resilience of highly susceptible crops through engineering or breeding.

With respect to our third goal, we profiled cell-type specific gene activity in environments including highly controlled laboratory growth chambers, temperature-controlled greenhouses, and agricultural fields. We validated that cell-specific signatures of gene activity are generally consistent across environments, with remarkably limited variation in signatures between roots of rice grown in the greenhouse or paddy field. For both the second and third goals, our discoveries, data and computational methods have and will continue to become accessible through scientific publications and public data repositories.

In the future, we will further investigate stimulus-responsive gene regulation in specific cell types, by developing and applying new methodologies that will allow us to specifically examine cells as they actively respond to a given stimulus. The tools and experimental approaches we have and continue to engineered can have wide application to plant and non-plant species.

In addition to the intellectual merit of our new research tools and the discovery of new biological principles, we made significant strides in training the next generation of scientists and educating the public on the significance of plant biology. Our interactions with the public included talks to lay audiences interested in science and hands-on learning activities with hundreds of students from diverse backgrounds in grades 5-12 and community college. We used multimedia, on and off-campus visitations, learning modules, as well as short and long term internships to educate and inspire others about plant biology, genomics and agriculture.
